transcript:
Therapist: Let's start by reviewing your experience with the Downward Arrow Technique. Can you walk me through how you've been using it since our last session?

Patient: Well, I tried to use it a few times when I noticed myself getting stuck in negative thoughts. For example, when I was working on the bookshelf project and I made a mistake, my first thought was "I'm so incompetent, I can't even do this simple task." Using the Downward Arrow Technique, I asked myself what that meant about me, and I realized that I have this underlying belief that I'm just not good enough, no matter what I do.

Therapist: That's a great example of using the technique to uncover a core belief. Identifying these deeper beliefs is an important step in challenging them. What was it like for you to recognize that belief?

Patient: It was tough, honestly. It's not easy to face those deep-seated negative beliefs about myself. But at the same time, it felt a bit empowering to put a name to it, you know? Like, now that I know what I'm really dealing with, I can start to work on changing it.

Therapist: Absolutely, that's the power of identifying these core beliefs. It gives us a target to work on. And you're right, it can be uncomfortable to face them head-on, but that's how we start to make real change. I'm curious, did you notice any other core beliefs coming up as you practiced this technique?

Patient: Yeah, another one that kept coming up was the belief that I'm unlovable. Like, when my daughter didn't respond to my text right away, my mind went straight to "She doesn't care about me, I'm just a burden to her."

Therapist: That's another great example. These beliefs about being incompetent or unlovable can really color how we interpret situations, even when there might be other explanations. Let's practice challenging these core beliefs using the evidence you've gathered. What evidence do you have that contradicts the belief that you're incompetent?

Patient: Well, I guess I have completed a lot of projects successfully in the past. And even with the bookshelf, I've made progress and figured out how to fix my mistakes. So that shows that I am capable, even if I'm not perfect.

Therapist: Exactly! Focusing on the evidence that contradicts the negative belief can help us start to build a more balanced perspective. And what about the belief that you're unlovable? What evidence do you have against that?

Patient: It's harder to find evidence against that one, but I suppose the fact that my daughter does still talk to me and invite me to family gatherings shows that she does care, even if our relationship is strained right now. And I have friends from my veterans group who seem to genuinely enjoy my company.

Therapist: Those are great examples of evidence against the belief that you're unlovable. It might take more time and practice to fully challenge these core beliefs, but you're off to a great start. Remember, the goal isn't to replace negative beliefs with overly positive ones, but rather to develop a more balanced and realistic perspective.

Patient: That makes sense. It's not about convincing myself that I'm perfect or that everything is fine, but just recognizing that there are shades of gray.

Therapist: Exactly. And as we continue to practice challenging these beliefs, it will start to feel more natural to think in those shades of gray, rather than getting stuck in all-or-nothing thinking. Speaking of all-or-nothing thinking, that's actually one of the cognitive distortions I wanted to introduce today. Cognitive distortions are like mental filters that can skew our perception of reality. All-or-nothing thinking, also called black-and-white thinking, is when we see things in extreme terms, without acknowledging the middle ground. Does that resonate with you at all?

Patient: Yeah, I can definitely see how I fall into that trap. Like, with the bookshelf project, I feel like if it's not perfect, then it's a total failure. There's no in-between.

Therapist: That's a perfect example of all-or-nothing thinking. And you can see how that type of thinking can fuel those core beliefs we were just talking about, like the belief that you're incompetent. Another cognitive distortion that might be relevant for you is disqualifying the positive, where you dismiss or downplay positive experiences or feedback. For example, you might get a compliment on your work, but you tell yourself it doesn't count because the person doesn't really know what they're talking about.

Patient: Oh yeah, I do that all the time. Like, if someone praises my work, I just assume they're being nice or they don't have very high standards.

Therapist: That's a great insight. Learning to recognize these cognitive distortions is the first step in challenging them. As we move forward, we can practice noticing when you're falling into these patterns and work on reframing those thoughts in a more balanced way. How do you feel about that?

Patient: It sounds challenging, but I'm willing to give it a try. I can see how these distortions are really holding me back and fueling my negative beliefs.

Therapist: That's great to hear. And remember, it's a process. We're not going to eliminate these distortions overnight, but with practice, we can start to shift those patterns. I have an idea for a homework assignment that can help with this. What if you keep a log this week of times when you notice yourself falling into all-or-nothing thinking or disqualifying the positive? Just jot down the situation, the distorted thought, and then try to reframe it in a more balanced way. We can review it together at our next session. What do you think?

Patient: That sounds like a good exercise. I'll give it a shot. It'll be hard to catch myself in the moment, but I'll do my best.

Therapist: That's all we can ask for. And even if you don't catch it in the moment, you can always reflect on it later and write it down then. The more you practice, the easier it will get to notice these distortions in real-time.

Patient: Okay, I'll definitely try to be more mindful of my thought patterns this week and write them down.

Therapist: Great. And remember, this is just one piece of the puzzle. We'll keep working on challenging those core beliefs and building up your coping skills in other areas too. Speaking of coping skills, how has your sleep been lately? We talked last time about how poor sleep can exacerbate depressive symptoms.
